Viewport¶

class pygly.viewport.Viewport(window, rect)[source]¶

A wrapper around the basic viewport functionality.

__init__(window, rect)[source]¶

Creates a viewport with the size of rect.

Automatically hooks into the window’s ‘on_resize’ event.

Args:
window: The window the viewport belongs to. rect: An array with the shape (2,2). Values are in pixels Values may exceed the window size but will be off the screen.

Note

OpenGL places platform-dependent limits on how far off screen a viewport may go.

aspect_ratio[source]¶

Returns the aspect ratio of the viewport.

Aspect ratio is the ratio of width to height a value of 2.0 means width is 2*height

Note

This is an @property decorated method which allows retrieval and assignment of the scale value.

bottom[source]¶

The bottom most point of the viewport in pixels.

event_types = ['on_viewport_resize', 'on_change_aspect_ratio']¶
height[source]¶

The height of the viewport in pixels.

left[source]¶

The left most point of the viewport in pixels.

on_resize(width, height)[source]¶

Event handler for pyglet window’s on_resize event.

Called when the window is resized.

This is a stub function and is intended to be over-ridden.

pop_viewport_attributes()[source]¶

Pops the OGL attributes.

Called when tearing down viewport.

Note

This method mirrors ‘push_viewport_attributes’

position[source]¶

The origin of the viewport in pixels as a 2D vector.

This is the bottom left corner.

push_viewport_attributes()[source]¶

Pushes the current OGL attributes and then calls self.setup_viewport.

rect[source]¶

The viewports 2D rectangle in pixels.

Note

Changing this value will dispatch an

‘on_viewport_resize’ and ‘on_change_aspect_ratio’ events.

Returns:
The viewport size in pixels in the form of a NumPy with shape (2,2).
right[source]¶

The right most point of the viewport in pixels.

scissor_to_viewport()[source]¶

Calls glScissor with the size of the viewport.

Note

It is up to the user to call glEnable(GL_SCISSOR_TEST).

See also

Function pygly.gl.set_scissor() Documentation of the pygly.gl.set_scissor() function.

setup_viewport()[source]¶

Sets the viewport rendering attributes.

Over-ride this method to customise the opengl settings for this viewport.

The default method sets the following:
  1. glEnable( GL_DEPTH_TEST )
  2. glShadeModel( GL_SMOOTH )
  3. glEnable( GL_RESCALE_NORMAL )
  4. glEnable( GL_SCISSOR_TEST )
size[source]¶

The size of the viewport in pixels as a 2D vector.

switch_to()[source]¶

Calls glViewport which sets up the viewport for rendering.

@see pygly.gl.set_viewport.

top[source]¶

The top most point of the viewport in pixels.

width[source]¶

The width of the viewport in pixels.

x[source]¶

The X value of the viewport in pixels.

This is the X value of the bottom left corner.

y[source]¶

The Y value of the viewport in pixels.

This is the Y value of the bottom left corner.

class pygly.ratio_viewport.RatioViewport(window, ratio)[source]¶

Maintains a set size ratio within a window.

A RatioViewport will automatically resize itself when the window is resized, to maintain a specific ratio of the window size.

__init__(window, ratio)[source]¶

Creates a viewport with the specified ratio.

Automatically hooks into the window’s ‘on_resize’ event.

Args:
window: The window the viewport belongs to. rect: The viewport size as a ratio (percentage) of the window in the form of a NumPy array with the shape (2,2). Values are in percentages (0.0 -> 1.0). Values may exceed the window size but will be off the screen.

Note

OpenGL places platform-dependent limits on how far off screen a viewport may go.

on_resize(width, height)[source]¶

Event handler to be called when the window is resized.

Args:
width (int): The width, in pixels, of the window’s renderable area. height (int): The height, in pixels, of the window’s renderable area.
ratio[source]¶

The viewport’s ratio.

Note

This is an @property decorated method which allows retrieval and assignment of the scale value.

See also

Module pygly.gl Documentation of the pygly.gl module. Contains viewport controls.
